composer.name: Orlando Gibbons
composer.bio: Orlando Gibbons was an English composer, virginalist and organist of the late Tudor and early Jacobean periods. He was a leading composer in England in the early 17th century and a key figure in the transition from the Renaissance to the Baroque period.

career.event: Entered the Choir of King's College, Cambridge
career.description: At the age of 13, Gibbons became a member of the choir at King's College, Cambridge, where he began his formal musical education.
Gibbons became a Gentleman of the Chapel Royal, serving as organist and composer for King James I.
Awarded a Bachelor of Music degree from the University of Cambridge.
Released 'The First Set of Madrigals and Mottets of 5 Parts', which contained some of his most famous secular compositions.

career.event: Appointed as organist at Westminster Abbey
career.description: While maintaining his position at the Chapel Royal, Gibbons also became the organist at Westminster Abbey.

career.event: Appointed as organist at Canterbury Cathedral
career.description: Added the prestigious position of organist at Canterbury Cathedral to his duties.
Died suddenly of apoplexy (likely a stroke) while in Canterbury for a state visit by King Charles I and his queen.

compositions.title: The Silver Swan
compositions.description: Perhaps Gibbons' most famous madrigal, noted for its beautiful text painting and expressing the legend that swans sing only at the moment of their death.
compositions.fragment: The silver Swan, who living had no Note, when Death approached, unlocked her silent throat.

compositions.title: O Clap Your Hands
compositions.description: An exuberant eight-part anthem displaying Gibbons' mastery of polyphonic writing for double choir.
compositions.fragment: O clap your hands, all ye people: shout unto God with the voice of triumph.

compositions.title: This Is the Record of John
compositions.description: A verse anthem for solo voice and chorus, with text from the Gospel of John, showing his innovative approach to sacred music.
compositions.fragment: This is the record of John, when the Jews sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him, Who art thou?

compositions.title: Fantasia in Four Parts
compositions.description: An intricate contrapuntal piece for viols displaying Gibbons' mastery of instrumental writing.

compositions.title: Lord Salisbury Pavane
compositions.description: A stately keyboard piece composed in memory of Robert Cecil, the 1st Earl of Salisbury.

locations.name: Chapel Royal
locations.description: The Chapel Royal is not a building but a body of singers and priests who serve the spiritual needs of the monarch. Gibbons served here under King James I.
locations.historical_fact: The Chapel Royal was the primary venue for the development of English church music from Tudor times onward.

locations.name: King's College, Cambridge
locations.description: Famous for its chapel and choir, King's College is where Gibbons received his early musical training as a chorister.
locations.historical_fact: The choir of King's College Chapel has maintained the tradition of singing daily services since its foundation in 1441.

locations.name: Westminster Abbey
locations.description: Gibbons served as organist at this royal church and Anglican cathedral in London, the traditional place of coronation and burial for English monarchs.
locations.historical_fact: Westminster Abbey houses the graves of many famous composers, including Henry Purcell and George Frideric Handel.

locations.name: Canterbury Cathedral
locations.description: The cathedral where Gibbons worked as organist late in his career and where he died suddenly in 1625.
locations.historical_fact: Canterbury Cathedral has been a site of Christian worship for over 1400 years and is the cathedral of the Archbishop of Canterbury.

locations.name: Royal Courts of James I
locations.description: The court of King James I was a center of artistic patronage where Gibbons composed and performed much of his music.
locations.historical_fact: King James I was a significant patron of the arts and commissioned the King James Bible, completed in 1611.

musical_terms.definition: A secular vocal music composition of the Renaissance and early Baroque periods, typically written for four to six voices in complex contrapuntal style.
A choral composition with English text, usually sacred, designed for use in Anglican church services.
A type of anthem popular in the late 16th and 17th centuries that alternates between sections for solo voice and full choir.
An instrumental composition with a free form and often improvisatory style, typically for keyboard or consort of viols.
A slow processional dance common in Europe during the 16th century, often paired with a faster galliard.
A small rectangular harpsichord popular in the 16th and 17th centuries, particularly in England.

tudor_period.description: The Tudor period marked the transition from medieval to early modern England, with significant religious reforms and cultural developments.

stuart_period.description: The Stuart period saw the unification of the English and Scottish crowns, Civil War, and restoration of the monarchy.

english_renaissance.description: A period of cultural and artistic flourishing in England in the late 16th and early 17th centuries, marked by advances in literature, drama, and music.

significant_contemporaries.name: William Byrd
significant_contemporaries.relationship: Older contemporary and possible mentor to Gibbons, considered the greatest English composer of his time.

significant_contemporaries.name: Thomas Weelkes
significant_contemporaries.relationship: Fellow composer of madrigals and church music, served as organist at Chichester Cathedral.

significant_contemporaries.name: William Shakespeare
significant_contemporaries.relationship: Greatest dramatist of the age, whose career overlapped with Gibbons' life and work.

significant_contemporaries.name: John Donne
significant_contemporaries.relationship: Metaphysical poet and Anglican priest whose literary career coincided with Gibbons' musical one.
